acts.title: Electrification
acts.description: The mechanical age couldn't scale. Gears were slow, expensive, and imprecise. But electricity changed everything. With the click of a relay, signals could travel at the speed of light, and calculations that took hours could be done in seconds. From the 1890 census crisis to WWII's desperate need for computation, electricity would transform calculation into computing.

chapters.title: The Census Crisis
chapters.subtitle: United States Census Bureau, Washington D.C.

setting.text: Lincoln, England, 1854. In a modest study, a largely self-taught mathematician puts down his pen. He has just completed 'An Investigation of the Laws of Thought'â€”a work that will transform human reasoning into algebra.

narrative: George Boole has done something revolutionary: he has proven that logic itself can be expressed as mathematics. AND, OR, NOTâ€”the fundamental operations of human reasoningâ€”can be written as equations.
His insight seems abstract, almost philosophical. What use is an algebra of thought? The answer won't come for nearly a century, but when it does, it will power every digital computer ever built.
Boole's algebra reduces all logical statements to two values: TRUE (1) and FALSE (0). Any argument, any deduction, any chain of reasoning can be expressed as operations on these binary values.

characters.name: George Boole
characters.title: Mathematician & Logician
characters.bio: A self-educated English mathematician who became professor at Queen's College Cork. His Boolean algebra would become the mathematical foundation of digital computingâ€”though he never lived to see it applied to machines.

technicalNotes.content: Boolean algebra defines operations on binary values: AND (both must be true), OR (either can be true), NOT (invert). These three operations are sufficient to express any logical functionâ€”and they map directly to physical switches, relays, and transistors.

setting.text: The Census Bureau building in Washington D.C., 1888. Mountains of paper forms overflow from every desk, every shelf, every corner. The air is thick with dust and desperation. The 1880 census took eight years to tabulateâ€”and America is growing faster than ever.

narrative: You've been assigned to the Census Bureau's statistics division. Your job: help tabulate the nation's population. By hand. One card at a time.
The 1880 census counted 50 million Americans. The 1890 census will count over 62 million. At the current pace, the tabulation won't be finished before the 1900 census begins.
Something has to change. But what?

characters.name: Robert Porter
characters.title: Superintendent of the Census
characters.bio: A man caught between political pressure and mathematical reality. The Constitution requires a census every ten years. The math says it's impossible. Porter needs a miracleâ€”or a machine.

dialogues.speaker: Porter
dialogues.text: At our current rate, we'll still be counting 1890 when it's time to start 1900. Congress won't accept that. The Constitution won't accept that. We need a new approach.

technicalNotes.content: The 1880 census employed 1,500 clerks working full-time for eight years to tabulate 50 million people. Each person's data had to be manually transferred to tally sheets, cross-checked, and aggregatedâ€”a process prone to errors and utterly unscalable.

setting.text: A competition has been announced: invent a machine that can tabulate the census faster. The prize: a government contract worth millions. The deadline: demonstrate results before the enumeration begins.

narrative: Three inventors have entered the competition. One of themâ€”a young engineer named Herman Hollerithâ€”has an idea inspired by train conductors.
On trains, conductors punch holes in tickets to encode passenger information: gender, hair color, height. Why not encode census data the same wayâ€”on cards that machines can read?

characters.name: Herman Hollerith
characters.title: Inventor & Engineer
characters.bio: German-American inventor who worked briefly at the Census Bureau and saw the tabulation nightmare firsthand. His solution combines punch cards (borrowed from Jacquard looms) with electrical sensingâ€”a machine that can 'read' data.

dialogues.speaker: Hollerith
dialogues.text: Each person becomes a card. Each fact about themâ€”age, sex, birthplace, occupationâ€”becomes a hole in a specific position. The machine reads the holes by passing electricity through them.

dialogues.speaker: Porter
dialogues.text: Electricity? Through paper cards? Can it really work?

dialogues.speaker: Hollerith
dialogues.text: Watch.

setting.text: Hollerith's workshop. The tabulating machine stands ready: a wooden cabinet with a card reader, a bank of clock-like dials, and a sorting box with dozens of compartments.

narrative: The punch card sits in a press. Metal pins descend onto the cardâ€”where there's a hole, the pin passes through into a cup of mercury below, completing an electrical circuit.
That circuit increments a counter. Sort a thousand cards and you have a thousand tallies, categorized automatically.

But the real magic is in the sorter. Based on which holes are punched, the machine opens one of forty compartments. Cards sort themselves by state, by age, by occupationâ€”whatever categories you need.

technicalNotes.content: Hollerith's tabulator used mercury cups as electrical contacts. When a pin found a hole, it dipped into mercury, completing a circuit that advanced an electromechanical counter. The sorting mechanism used electromagnets to open specific compartment doors. This was the first practical electromechanical data processing system.

setting.text: The competition results are in. Hollerith's machine is ten times faster than the second-place entry. The Census Bureau has found its miracle.

narrative: But success brings new questions. Hollerith's machine can countâ€”but can it calculate? Can it cross-tabulate? Can it find correlations that no human would notice?
The data is there, encoded in holes. The question is: what can we do with it?

choices.title: Learn to Operate the Tabulator
choices.description: Master the Hollerith machine. Understand punch cards, pin readers, and electromechanical counters.

choices.title: Design a Punch Card System
choices.description: Create your own encoding scheme. Decide what data to capture and how to represent it in holes.

choices.title: Consider the Implications
choices.description: Machines that process data about people. What does this mean for privacy, for government power, for society?

setting.text: The tabulating room. Rows of Hollerith machines click rhythmically as operators feed punch cards through the readers.

dialogues.speaker: Hollerith
dialogues.text: Watch the operator. She places the card on the reader, pulls the lever down. The pins descendâ€”where there's a hole, the pin passes through into mercury, completing the circuit.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: And the dials? They're counting automatically?

dialogues.speaker: Hollerith
dialogues.text: Each circuit connects to an electromechanical counter. Forty dials, forty counts. The operator just feeds cardsâ€”the machine does the mathematics. Eighty cards per minute, error-free.

technicalNotes.content: The Hollerith tabulator's mercury cups provided reliable electrical contact. When a pin found a hole, it dipped into mercuryâ€”a liquid metal that conducted electricity perfectly. This simple mechanism enabled reliable detection of binary patterns at mechanical speed.

setting.text: A drafting table with blank punch card templates. Hollerith explains the art of encoding information.

dialogues.speaker: Hollerith
dialogues.text: The card has 45 columns, 10 rows. Each column can encode one digit, 0-9. But here's the clever part: combinations of holes can represent more complex data.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: So two holes in one column could mean something different than either hole alone?

dialogues.speaker: Hollerith
dialogues.text: Exactly! This is the foundation of encoding. Later cards will use 80 columns and encode letters, numbers, and special characters. But the principle is the same: patterns of holes represent data.

technicalNotes.content: The 80-column card (introduced 1928) became the standard for 50 years. The EBCDIC and ASCII encodings translated characters into hole patterns. The physical dimensions of the cardâ€”7.375 x 3.25 inchesâ€”were based on the 1887 US dollar bill, so existing money-handling machinery could process them.

setting.text: A quiet moment in the census building. The implications of machine-readable personal data are just beginning to be understood.

dialogues.speaker: Clerk
dialogues.text: These machines know things about people. Where they live. What they do. Where they came from. All searchable. All countable. All sortable.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: Is that dangerous?

dialogues.speaker: Clerk
dialogues.text: In America, we use it for census statistics. But imagine if a government wanted to find everyone of a certain religion, or ethnicity, or political belief. The same technology that counts us can also... categorize us.

technicalNotes.content: This concern proved tragically prescient. During WWII, Hollerith technology (by then owned by IBM) was used by Nazi Germany to identify and track Jewish populations. The Dehomag subsidiary's tabulators processed census data that facilitated the Holocaust.

setting.text: The tabulating room. Rows of machines await, each attended by an operator. Your task: design an encoding scheme and process a batch of census records.

narrative: Each punch card has positions for different data fields. You must decide: which positions encode age? Which encode birthplace? How do you handle the 50 states and territories?
The encoding is the first step. Then comes the tabulationâ€”setting up the counters to answer specific questions about the population.

objectives.text: Design a punch card encoding for census data
Process a batch of cards through the tabulator

technicalNotes.content: Punch card encoding is the ancestor of all data representation. A hole represents 1, no hole represents 0â€”pure binary. The Hollerith system used 12 rows and up to 80 columns, giving 960 potential bits per card. This format survived until the 1970s.

setting.text: Six weeks later. The preliminary census results are readyâ€”years ahead of schedule. The nation is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Porter
dialogues.text: The count is complete: 62,979,766 Americans. We've finished the rough count in six weeks. Six weeks! The 1880 census took eight years!

dialogues.speaker: Hollerith
dialogues.text: The machines work. But this is just the beginning. We can cross-tabulate any combination of factors. Age by state. Occupation by birthplace. Anything you can encode, we can count.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: What's next? More censuses?

dialogues.speaker: Hollerith
dialogues.text: Railroads. Insurance companies. Banks. Anyone with data to process. I'm founding a company to build these machines. In fifty years, every business in America will have one.

narrative: Hollerith's company would eventually become IBM. The punch card would dominate data processing for eighty years. And the principleâ€”encoding information as patterns that machines can readâ€”would become the foundation of all digital computing.
But electromechanical counters had limits. They could count, but they couldn't truly calculate. They couldn't make decisions. They couldn't be programmed.
For that, the world would need a different kind of machineâ€”and a different kind of war.

setting.text: Berlin, Germany. 1936. While Hitler prepares for the Olympics, a young civil engineer works alone in his parents' apartment, surrounded by telephone relays, metal strips, and hand-drawn schematics. His name is Konrad Zuse.

narrative: Zuse's job designing aircraft structures requires endless calculations: stress analysis, load distributions, structural dynamics. Each calculation takes hours of tedious arithmetic.
"There has to be a better way," he mutters, staring at yet another page of hand calculations. "What if a machine could do this?"
He doesn't know about Babbage. He doesn't know about the Hollerith machines. He's reinventing computation from scratchâ€”and he's about to leapfrog everyone.

characters.name: Konrad Zuse
characters.title: Civil Engineer & Inventor
characters.bio: A practical engineer who hated tedious calculation so much that he invented the programmable computer to avoid it. Working in isolation, Zuse independently developed binary arithmetic, floating-point numbers, and stored-program concepts.

dialogues.speaker: Zuse
dialogues.text: The calculating machines I've seen use decimalâ€”ten positions per digit. That's wasteful. A switch has only two states: on and off. Why not compute in binary?

technicalNotes.content: Zuse independently invented binary computation, believing it more natural for machines. He also developed floating-point arithmetic and a notation for programs (PlankalkÃ¼l) decades before these ideas became mainstream. His isolationâ€”both geographical and due to the warâ€”meant his work was largely unknown until the 1960s.

setting.text: The apartment is transformed into a workshop. Zuse's mother tolerates the mess; his father funds the components. Old telephone relays click and clatter as prototypes evolve.

narrative: The Z1 takes shape: mechanical memory using slotted metal plates, a mechanical arithmetic unit, and a program reader using punched film from discarded movie reels.
It's brilliant. It's innovative. And it barely worksâ€”the mechanical parts jam constantly, the tolerances too tight for hand-built components.
But Zuse learns from failure. The Z2 replaces mechanical logic with telephone relays. The Z3 will be fully relay-basedâ€”and fully programmable.

dialogues.speaker: Zuse
dialogues.text: The mechanical system is too fragile. But telephone relays... they're designed for millions of operations. Reliable. Fast. Perfect for computation.

technicalNotes.content: The Z1 (1938) was purely mechanicalâ€”and constantly jammed. The Z2 (1940) used relay-based arithmetic but mechanical memory. The Z3 (1941) was fully relay-based: 2,600 relays, binary floating-point arithmetic, and program control. It was the world's first programmable, automatic digital computer.

setting.text: May 1941. The Z3 is complete. It fills Zuse's workshop with clicking relays, punched film looping through the reader. The world's first working programmable computer.

narrative: But the war is escalating. The German government shows little interest in Zuse's "thinking machine." Resources go to tanks and rockets, not computational abstractions.
Zuse dreams of a more powerful machineâ€”the Z4â€”with more memory, faster operation. But can he build it before the war catches up?

choices.title: Study the Z3 Architecture
choices.description: Examine the world's first programmable computer. Understand relay logic, binary arithmetic, and program control.

choices.title: Master Floating-Point
choices.description: Learn Zuse's floating-point format. Understand why separating exponent and mantissa enables vast numeric ranges.

choices.title: Roads Not Taken: What If Germany Had Invested?
choices.description: If the Nazis had funded Zuse fully, computing history might look very different. Explore this alternate path.

setting.text: Inside the Z3. Relays click in precise patterns as the machine performs a calculation. Zuse explains the architecture.

dialogues.speaker: Zuse
dialogues.text: The Z3 has three parts: the memory, the arithmetic unit, and the control unit. Memory stores 64 words of 22 bits each. The arithmetic unit performs addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and square root.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: And the control unit reads the program from film?

dialogues.speaker: Zuse
dialogues.text: Yes! Discarded 35mm movie film, punched with hole patterns. Each frame contains one instruction. The machine reads the film, decodes the instruction, and executes it. Fully automatic, fully programmable.

technicalNotes.content: The Z3's architecture presaged modern computers: separate memory, ALU, and control unit. Its 22-bit word used 1 sign bit, 7 exponent bits, and 14 mantissa bitsâ€”a floating-point format remarkably similar to later standards.

setting.text: A chalkboard covered with mathematical notation. Zuse explains his floating-point innovation.

dialogues.speaker: Zuse
dialogues.text: Engineers need to calculate with very large and very small numbers. Wing stress might be 10^6, while a tolerance is 10^-6. Fixed-point can't handle both. Floating-point can.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: So you separate the size from the precision?

dialogues.speaker: Zuse
dialogues.text: Exactly! The mantissa holds the significant digits, the exponent scales them. 1.234 Ã— 10^6 and 1.234 Ã— 10^-6 use the same mantissaâ€”only the exponent differs. One format handles all engineering calculations.

technicalNotes.content: Zuse's floating-point format anticipated the IEEE 754 standard by 45 years. His insightâ€”that scientific computing requires both range and precisionâ€”became fundamental to all computer arithmetic. Every GPU, CPU, and calculator today uses floating-point.

setting.text: A contemplative moment. What if history had taken a different path?

dialogues.speaker: Zuse
dialogues.text: I asked the government for resources to build a more powerful machine. They refused. Tanks and rockets, they said. No interest in computing machines.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: What if they had funded you?

dialogues.speaker: Zuse
dialogues.text: With proper resources, I could have built the Z4 three years earlier. Vacuum tube machines by 1944. Perhaps... but no. Such power in their hands would have been terrible. Perhaps it's better the relay clicked slowly in my workshop.

technicalNotes.content: The Nazi regime's failure to invest in computing was a strategic blunder. While Germany built V-2 rockets with slide rules, Britain's Colossus broke German codes and America's ENIAC calculated artillery tables. Computing power proved as decisive as military hardware.

setting.text: Your workshop bench is configured as a relay computer simulator. Build the core of Zuse's Z3: binary arithmetic using relay logic.

narrative: A relay is a switch controlled by an electromagnet. When current flows through the coil, the switch closes. When current stops, the switch opens. On or off. 1 or 0.
Chain relays together and you can compute: AND gates, OR gates, adders, multipliers. The clicking becomes thinking.

objectives.text: Build a half-adder from relay logic
Chain half-adders into a full adder

technicalNotes.content: Relay logic directly implements Boolean algebra. A relay in series = AND (both must be energized). Relays in parallel = OR (either can complete the circuit). A normally-closed relay = NOT (energizing opens it). These are the fundamental operations of all digital computers.

setting.text: April 1945. Berlin burns. The Z3 was destroyed in a bombing raid in 1943. But Zuse escaped with the Z4, hidden in a village in Bavaria. The war ends.

dialogues.speaker: Zuse
dialogues.text: The Z3 is gone. But the Z4 survives. And the ideas... the ideas cannot be bombed.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: Did the government ever realize what you'd built?

dialogues.speaker: Zuse
dialogues.text: No. They wanted weapons, not mathematics. If they had understood... but perhaps it's better they didn't. This technology should serve humanity, not destroy it.

narrative: After the war, Zuse would found a computer company that built Germany's first commercial computers. But by then, American and British machines had taken the leadâ€”developed with military funding he never received.
Still, Zuse's legacy endures: binary arithmetic, floating-point computation, and the stored-program concept. He proved that relay computers could think.
But relays were slow. Thousands of operations per second, not millions. The next breakthrough would require something fasterâ€”something with no moving parts at all.

setting.text: Bell Telephone Laboratories, New York City, September 1940. A telephone engineer named George Stibitz is about to make historyâ€”with a demonstration that predicts the future of computing by sixty years.

narrative: In his home kitchen in 1937, Stibitz had built a circuit from telephone relays that could add binary numbers. His wife dubbed it the 'Model K'â€”for kitchen table. It seemed like a parlor trick.

But Bell Labs saw potential. Complex numbers are essential for analyzing electrical circuits, and calculating them by hand was tedious. Stibitz built the Complex Number Calculator: a room full of relays that could multiply complex numbers.
Today, at a mathematics conference at Dartmouth College, Stibitz will demonstrate something unprecedented: remote computing over a telephone line.

characters.name: George Stibitz
characters.title: Bell Labs Research Mathematician
characters.bio: A telephone engineer who built computing circuits from surplus relays on his kitchen table. His Complex Number Calculator was the first machine to perform remote computationâ€”the ancestor of every networked computer.

dialogues.speaker: Stibitz
dialogues.text: The machine is in New York City. We're in Dartmouth, New Hampshire. I'll type the problem on this teletype. The answer will come back over the telephone line. Watch.

technicalNotes.content: The 1940 Dartmouth demonstration was the first remote computation in history. Mathematicians including John von Neumann and Norbert Wiener watched as Stibitz typed problems on a teletype that transmitted over telephone lines to the Complex Number Calculator in NYCâ€”250 miles away. The results returned seconds later.

setting.text: Bletchley Park, Buckinghamshire, England. 1943. A country estate transformed into Britain's top-secret codebreaking center. Huts scattered across the grounds house mathematicians, linguists, and engineers working to crack German ciphers.

narrative: The German Enigma machine encrypts military communications. The British have broken itâ€”but the higher-level Lorenz cipher, used for Hitler's strategic communications, remains impenetrable.

The Lorenz machine generates pseudo-random bits that obscure the message. To break it, the codebreakers need to test billions of possible settings. By hand, it would take years. Years they don't have.
Enter Tommy Flowers, a Post Office engineer who proposes something radical: a machine that uses vacuum tubes instead of relays. Electronic, not electromechanical. Thousands of times faster.

characters.name: Tommy Flowers
characters.title: Engineer, General Post Office
characters.bio: A telephone engineer who believed vacuum tubes could be reliable if used correctlyâ€”running continuously rather than being switched on and off. His Colossus would be the world's first electronic digital computer.

stats.label: Key Insight
stats.value: Tubes fail when switched, not when running

characters.name: Alan Turing
characters.title: Mathematician, Codebreaker
characters.bio: The genius who laid the theoretical foundations of computation. His 1936 paper described a universal computing machine. At Bletchley, he applied that theory to break Enigma.

stats.label: Tragedy
stats.value: Persecuted for homosexuality after the war

technicalNotes.content: The Lorenz cipher was far more complex than Enigma. It used 12 wheels to generate pseudo-random bits, creating a key space of billions of possibilities. Colossus was designed specifically to find the wheel settings by statistical analysisâ€”counting patterns at electronic speed.

setting.text: December 1943. Colossus Mark I arrives at Bletchley Park. The largest vacuum tube machine ever built: 1,500 valves humming with electronic life.

narrative: The skeptics were wrong. Flowers designed Colossus to run continuouslyâ€”and tubes that never switch off rarely fail. The machine processes 5,000 characters per second, reading punched tape at 30 miles per hour.

But Colossus isn't a general-purpose computer. It's a specialized cryptanalysis engine, hardwired for one task: breaking Lorenz. The switches and plugboards configure it for different attacks, but the basic operation is fixed.

dialogues.speaker: Flowers
dialogues.text: They said vacuum tubes couldn't be reliable in such numbers. They were wrong. The secret is to never turn them off. A tube fails when it's heated and cooled. Keep it warm and it runs forever.

technicalNotes.content: Colossus used 1,500 vacuum tubes (Colossus Mark II used 2,400). By leaving them powered continuously and using high-quality components, Flowers achieved unprecedented reliability. The machine operated 24 hours a day with minimal failuresâ€”a feat many thought impossible.

setting.text: The Colossus room glows with the orange light of heated vacuum tubes. Wires snake across every surface. The machine hums with purposeâ€”breaking codes that change the course of the war.

narrative: By war's end, ten Colossus machines will be operating at Bletchley Park. Their work contributes to D-Day planning, reveals German troop movements, and saves countless lives.

But Colossus is a secret. After the war, Churchill orders most of the machines destroyed. Tommy Flowers burns his blueprints. The electronic computer, as far as the public knows, hasn't been invented yet.

choices.title: Study Colossus Architecture
choices.description: Examine the first electronic digital machine. Understand how vacuum tubes implement Boolean logic at electronic speed.

choices.title: Break a Lorenz Message
choices.description: Experience the cryptanalysis process. Use statistical methods to find the cipher wheel settings.

choices.title: Roads Not Taken: Turing's ACE
choices.description: Turing's post-war ACE design was more advanced than anything built until the 1960s. Return to your lab to construct his vision.

setting.text: Inside Colossus. Rack after rack of vacuum tubes glow orange. Tommy Flowers explains how electronic logic works.

dialogues.speaker: Flowers
dialogues.text: A vacuum tube is a switch with no moving parts. Apply voltage to the grid and current flows from cathode to plate. Remove voltage and it stops. On or off, in microseconds rather than milliseconds.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: But 1,500 tubesâ€”how do you keep them all working?

dialogues.speaker: Flowers
dialogues.text: The secret: never turn them off. Tubes fail when thermal stress cracks the glassâ€”heating and cooling, on and off. Leave them running continuously and they last for years. Colossus runs 24 hours a day.

technicalNotes.content: Colossus Mark I used 1,500 tubes; Mark II used 2,400. By selecting high-quality components and running continuously, Flowers achieved reliability that skeptics thought impossible. The machine operated at 5,000 characters per secondâ€”1,000 times faster than relay machines.

setting.text: A simplified Lorenz cipher demonstration. The mathematical attack becomes clear.

dialogues.speaker: Cryptanalyst
dialogues.text: The Lorenz cipher adds pseudo-random bits to the message. If we can guess the wheel settings that generated those bits, we can subtract them and read the plaintext.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: But there are billions of possible settings...

dialogues.speaker: Cryptanalyst
dialogues.text: True randomness has no pattern. But Lorenz's wheels create subtle statistical biases. Colossus counts these biases at electronic speed, testing millions of settings until the patterns emerge. Mathematics defeats machinery.

technicalNotes.content: The Lorenz attack exploited the delta method: XORing adjacent characters revealed patterns in the key stream. Colossus counted coincidences between the cipher tape and generated patterns, finding statistical anomalies that indicated correct wheel settings.

setting.text: After the war. Turing sketches his vision for the ACEâ€”a computer decades ahead of its time.

dialogues.speaker: Turing
dialogues.text: The ACE will store its program in memoryâ€”just like data. The same memory that holds numbers can hold instructions. The machine can modify its own program as it runs.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: A machine that rewrites itself?

dialogues.speaker: Turing
dialogues.text: Self-modifying code, subroutines stored in memory, even a form of microprogramming. My design is too advancedâ€”the bureaucrats don't understand it. They'll build something simpler and call it progress.

technicalNotes.content: Turing's ACE design (1945) included concepts not widely implemented until the 1960s: microprogramming, subroutine linkage, and hardware-assisted context switching. The full ACE was never built; a simplified 'Pilot ACE' ran in 1950.

setting.text: Your simulation bench configures to mimic electronic logic. Build the core of Colossus: vacuum tube gates running at electronic speed.

narrative: A vacuum tube triode can amplify signalsâ€”small input, large output. But it can also switch: grid voltage controls plate current, on or off.
Two triodes in series: AND gate. Two triodes in parallel: OR gate. Add an inverting output: NOT gate. The building blocks of digital logic, now running at megahertz instead of hertz.

objectives.text: Implement NOT gate using triode cutoff

technicalNotes.content: Vacuum tubes operate by thermionic emission: a heated cathode releases electrons, which flow to the plate if not blocked by negative voltage on the grid. Switching speed is limited by electron transit time and capacitanceâ€”microseconds instead of relay milliseconds.

setting.text: May 1945. The war in Europe ends. Colossus has served its purpose. Soon, most will be dismantled, their secrets locked away for decades.

dialogues.speaker: Turing
dialogues.text: Colossus proved that electronic computation works. But it's specializedâ€”hardwired for cryptanalysis. I want to build a universal machine. A machine that can be programmed to do anything.

dialogues.speaker: Flowers
dialogues.text: The technology is ready. We know vacuum tubes can be reliable. We know electronic logic can be fast. The question is: what do we build next?

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: What about the Americans? Are they building electronic computers too?

dialogues.speaker: Turing
dialogues.text: I've heard rumors. Something at the University of Pennsylvania. Artillery calculations. They're calling it ENIAC.

narrative: The relay era ends here. Zuse proved that programmable machines could work. Colossus proved that electronic speed was achievable.
But the next stepâ€”a general-purpose electronic computer, stored-program control, the architecture that would define computing for decadesâ€”awaits across the Atlantic.
The Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer is about to change everything.

setting.text: Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts, August 1944. In the basement of the Cruft Laboratory, the largest electromechanical computer ever built clicks and whirs: 51 feet long, 8 feet tall, 5 tons of relays, gears, and wires.

narrative: Howard Aiken had a vision: a machine that could perform any mathematical operation, automatically, without human intervention. He convinced IBM to fund it. The result is the Harvard Mark Iâ€”officially the IBM Automatic Sequence Controlled Calculator.

The Mark I is a hybrid: electromechanical relays perform logic, but mechanical counters handle numbers. It's slow by electronic standardsâ€”three seconds for a multiplicationâ€”but it runs 24 hours a day, calculating naval ballistics tables for the war effort.
A young Navy Lieutenant named Grace Hopper has been assigned to program it. She will become the first of a new breed: the computer programmer.

characters.name: Howard Aiken
characters.title: Commander, Harvard Computation Laboratory
characters.bio: A physicist who dreamed of a general-purpose calculating machine and persuaded IBM to build it. The Mark I was the last great electromechanical computerâ€”and the training ground for the first programmers.

characters.name: Grace Hopper
characters.title: Lieutenant, US Navy Reserve
characters.bio: A mathematician and Navy officer who became one of the first programmers. She would later invent the first compiler and coin the term 'debugging' after removing a moth from the Mark II. Her influence on programming languages would be incalculable.

stats.label: Famous Quote
stats.value: 'It's easier to ask forgiveness than permission'

dialogues.speaker: Aiken
dialogues.text: The Navy needs firing tables. Each trajectory calculation would take a human computer twenty hours. The Mark I does it in minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Hopper
dialogues.text: But programming it is like solving a puzzle. Every operation, every branch, every loop must be planned in advance. We're not just operating a machineâ€”we're teaching it to think.

technicalNotes.content: The Harvard Mark I contained 765,000 components, 500 miles of wire, and 3 million connections. It could store 72 numbers of 23 digits each. Programs were fed on punched paper tape. Grace Hopper and her team developed many fundamental programming concepts while working on this machine.

setting.text: The Mark I hums steadily, paper tape feeding through its readers. Grace Hopper reviews the latest program with her team, planning calculations that will help win the war.

dialogues.speaker: Hopper
dialogues.text: We found a moth stuck in one of the relays yesterday. Caused a malfunction. I taped it into the logbookâ€”we're calling it 'debugging' now.

dialogues.speaker: You
dialogues.text: Is the Mark I the future of computing?

dialogues.speaker: Hopper
dialogues.text: It's a bridge. Relays are reliable but slow. I've heard about machines using vacuum tubesâ€”they're a thousand times faster. The future will be electronic.

dialogues.speaker: Aiken
dialogues.text: Perhaps. But someone still needs to tell the machine what to do. Programmingâ€”that's where the real challenge lies. And that's what Lieutenant Hopper is pioneering.
